title: Making Acoustic Side-Channel Attacks on Noisy Keyboards Viable with LLM-Assisted Spectrograms' "Typo" Correction
author: Seyyed Ali Ayati (Texas A&M University), Jin Hyun Park (Texas A&M University), Marcus Botacin (Texas A&M University), Yichen Cai (University of Toronto), ...
relevance_why: The integration of Large Language Models (LLMs) for error correction in acoustic side-channel attacks could enhance my research on audio-opacity in generative models and improve error detection in audio applications.
background: This work addresses the challenge of recovering typed information from acoustic emissions of noisy keyboards, leveraging transformer architectures for classification and correction tasks.
contribution: This paper introduces a hybrid framework combining Visual Transformers (VTs) and Large Language Models (LLMs) to enhance the accuracy of keystroke recovery in noisy environments.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods predominantly used Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) for noise-free scenarios but struggled under real-world ambient noises.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves on previous approaches by using VTs for long-term context learning and LLMs to correct typographical errors post-classification, significantly boosting accuracy.

key_innovation: Combines advanced neural architectures (VTs and LLMs) to address both the classification of noisy signals and the subsequent correction of errors.
real_world_impact: This approach could provide a practical solution for mitigating risks associated with keystroke interception in various noisy environments, enhancing information security.
limitations: The reliance on model size for performance efficiency poses challenges in resource-constrained scenarios.

new_terms.Acoustic Side-Channel Attacks (AS-CAs): **Acoustic Side-Channel Attacks (AS-CAs)** involve eavesdropping on the sound generated by devices (like keyboards) to infer sensitive information.
new_terms.Visual Transformers (VTs): **Visual Transformers (VTs)** are neural network architectures designed to process visual data, such as images or spectrograms, leveraging self-attention mechanisms.
